title: Mother-of-two, 34, is horrified to discover that anyone can access her smartphone
text:
A mother-of-two discovered that anyone can access her smartphone after she fitted it with a £2.70 screen protector from eBay.

Lisa Neilson, 34, from Castleford, in West Yorkshire, bought the gel cover to protect her new Samsung S10.

But to her horror, she discovered that the thumb print used to access the phone could be unlocked by anyone.

After setting up the fingerprint scanner using her right thumb, she found out she could also use her left thumb to unlock it.

Lisa Neilson, 34, from Castleford, in West Yorkshire, bought the gel cover to protect her new Samsung S10.

Mrs Neilson then asked her husband Wes, 34, to try it out and he could also get into the device.

She told The Sun: 'Anyone can access it and could get into the financial apps and transfer funds.'

Samsung has said that people should only use authorised screen protectors.

She added: 'This means that if anyone got hold of my phone they can access it and within moments could be into the financial apps and be transferring funds.

'It's a real concern.'

'We called Samsung because we thought there was a fault with the phone.

'The man in customer services took control of the phone remotely and went into all the settings and finally admitted it looked like a security breach.'

A Samsung spokesman told the newspaper: 'We're investigating this internally.

'We recommend all customers to use Samsung authorised accessories, specifically designed for Samsung products.'
description: Lisa Neilson, 34, from Castleford, in West Yorkshire, bought the gel cover to protect her new Samsung S10.
